subject: RE: [junit] Re: Asserting Equality Of Collection Elements
msgSnippet: ... For Lists, I agree; but often I use Collection when I do not want to be concerned about the indices of elements. ... ...which works if there are no
messageBody:
> Well, it is sensible to consider the order when comparing lists.

For Lists, I agree; but often I use "Collection" when I do not want to be
concerned about the indices of elements.

> if you do not want that, or you have to compare different or unknown
> collections:
>
> Set expected = new HashSet(expectedCollectionThatMightBeAList);
> Set actual = new HashSet(actualCollection);
> ...
> assertEquals(expected, actual);

...which works if there are no duplicate elements in either of the original
collections. If there are 7 Foos and 2 Bars in the one, there ought to be 7
and 2, respectively, in the other. Your approach does not check that.

What I really want is a Bag, dammit. Why didn't Java give us a Bag?!
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
President, Diaspar Software Services
Let's write software that people understand.
